comment:
This practice is one in which you are invited to come as you are.
All the things that you may see as distractions or things that are not working in your favor... use it.
Enjoy your time on the mat today!
Just what I needed today!
Feeling body expanding and coming in with breath all around 🕳🌬🔴♥

Hi Adriene.. Not sure if you ll see my message.. I am new to yoga.. Though I ve been following you in this quest of 30 days, I have just finished today's 16th day.. And my question is.. I am a bit stiff in my knees. I have problems with my left knee as well.. Though in this position.. I feel I my ankles are burning. I can't stand in this position for long.. Is it normal? Will the pain go? :( thank you so much for your lessons, much appreciated 🙏 lots of love!!

Adrienne I LOVE only focusing on the breath and learning new techniques in breathing.

I am currently reading “Breath” by James Nestor so this fits in perfectly.

Honestly if you did an entire 30 day challenge with no yoga and only expelling your wisdom of breathing and breathing techniques I would do it.

Kria yoga I have read about but hard to find some very in depth info or real practice on YouTube.

Love you and thank you so much. I love your personality, you glow.

I'm finally catching up today after a couple of hectic days when all I could  carve out for myself was just 10 minutes of yoga. Lovely practice to get back to BREATH. I feel groundead and ready for bed. Thank you Adriene & Benji. ❤🙏🏻
First time I've seen you wear socks, Adrienne!😀

I experience a lot of frustration with my breath because my asthma is very bad. My constant shortness of breath feels like i can never breathe enough air into my body. Thank you for this practice adriene, i need the discipline and exercises to desperately improve my vital capacity. 💚
I find it easier to breathe out than in. Does that grow when practicing?
Through this Breath journey I’ve been wondering what Benji was looking at out the window. Mystery solved! 🦌

I did the 30 day challenge in January and have enjoyed a daily practice since then. Today I don’t feel so well and have had to spend the day in bed. But I wanted to do some gentle yoga and remembered the breathing exercises of this 30 day series. I just followed this one - still in bed - and  although still feeling strange (I think its a post vaccine thing), I feel clearer and brighter. Many thanks to Adriene and all in the ywa community

This was very therapeutic for me today, after taking in a lot of bad news. It was a great chance to slow down and have something beneficial to focus on. Thanks for connecting us and giving us a sense of togetherness. Much love as always <3
Just what I needed today, my body has been feeling somewhat sore, so it was nice to have a calmer practice focusing more on the breath.
according to the view count, 71 of us practiced together just now! happy to have made it to day 16.
Thank you for being such a wonderful teacher and guide.🙏
OMG! I loved this practice. Thank you Adriene for sharing.

Disciplined today
Thank you namaste
Yey! Made it to the Day 16 of this Yoga Journey ☺️ (April 24 2021)
Good sock game both you and Benji. 8 plus 8, YOU’RE GREAT! 🙏🏻
Thank you❤❤❤😇
Thank you! 😊

I 100% did feel absolute stillness and just completely grounded,  like i was a little pin on the earth as it spins. after the 8 breath ratio. i found using the length and the core to control the breathe very useful in slowing down and having that as a focus. as if my tummy was letting air in and out of the bellows, or my lungs haha
Namaste :) you really make me smile :) :) :)
Much needed Thank you adreine adreine for bringing in so much peace to my life! God bless😇

My lungs always feel so exhausted after a practice and I cant seem to get past the hump of sore pecks but i can feel my roots growing deep into the earth, enriching me and i can feel my core becoming stronger and more self assured and so i continue to daily arrive. - Lee

Thank you for your guides & company on this journey it is very eye opening . See you tomorrow ..

DAY
I saw the deer legs !!!! Cutteee!!!! @0:39 to the leftttt - right after Adriene said it!!!

Holy smokes.

1. I avoided this day for a minute because Discipline is a red letter word for me.
2. I did and LOVED IT.
3. I'm back to do part of it again... I'm showing up even if it's just for part of it.
4. The minute I heard her voice my whole body started to relax... I think I've been converted!

On my first day slowing down my breath I didn’t love it. I struggled on breathing in the full 8 counts and it sort of made me sleepy lol. BUT I also didn’t love breath of fire on the first day and now I absolutely love it, so I won’t give up on this either 🙏🏼
I did this today and felt an over whelming experience of sadness at the end and tears came rolling down my face. Is that ok?

I bookmarked this video in my mind  for when I needed a moment of stillness (steelness if you will) and WOW. I really needed this video, but saw it was 27 minutes I didn't think I would finish. However, I close my eyes and began to  breath through all my worries and before I knew it. It was over. I feel amazing and ready for some deep sleep after this long day.
Fastest 27 Minutes of my life. Thank you adriene!

i found myself using the ocean breath when slowing down my breathing, idk how but it definitely worked for me. i checked my apple watch and i was lowering my blood pressure  by the time i was doing the 5 seconds in, 6 seconds out. such a calming and restorative day! 💞
weve been in lockdowns for 6 months where im from and your videos have been a saving grace for me. i dont think i can ever live without yoga anymore
Thank you ...!!!

Normally love Adiene and 2020 30 day was a godsend in lockdown. I’ve been doing 2021, but so disappointed- there is so much just sitting and breathing. Day 16 has just about finished me off. Please Adrienne let us move again and feel warm and feel as if we’ve actually done something.
Awsome thank's so much

Adriane’s trap for pranayama: Discipline
I managed to finish breath work for the 1st time, thank you teacher 🙏🏻
Oh my God, how did you know that today was my first day of period to create such a grea,calm,healing exercise??? Love you 😘
By the way how does yawning fit into this practice? Inhale? Exhale? LOL I yawn all the time during these videos! I'll see if I can time them better based on instruction haha

I'm surprised the long inhales were the hardest part for me. I could exhale for a count of 12 if I wanted, but inhaling for 6 I noticed tightness in my left lung. Hmm not sure whats happening there. Anyone else find inhaling more difficult than exhaling?

Adriene, thank you so much for this practice. I have been fighting with my family for a while and that got me down. To me you are a loving friend who I can be present with as I am. This practice was so comforting. Everyone who knows you is really lucky.
Incredible!

this day was the hardest yet. i didnt know how hard breathing would be? i cried like 4 times this video because my lungs cant expand while im sitting with posture. i think my stomach is too fat ? my upper abdomen and ribcage are so tight from sucking my stomach in since i was 10. i couldnt even get more than 5 seconds in and 5 seconds out before my upper abdomen hurt so bad from being stretched. todays the first day im not sure it can happen.

everyone else in the comments is like “yay i finally found stillness” and today was the first day i felt like i couldnt find it. no truer name than ‘discipline’ bc i feel like i was reprimanded by my own body and mind :( hopefully in a better place tomorrow but i have little hope for my breathing
The first time that I’ve ever cried after a yoga session with the sweet feeling of pure, absolute stillness and release something that I didn’t even know was blocking me. Thank you so much ☀️
I just found like a moment of exquisite stillness there. - Me too!!!! Thanks for Day 16! <3
that was so beautiful, I felt so connected with myself! definitely a practice I needed tonight and for future meditations! thank you Adrienne 💗

I don’t think I’m doing the inhales or exhales right 🥺 but I’m trying

Day 16👍

I love this one! I keep coming back to it. I wish there were more like this.

Hi Adriene, I'm doing this whole series, today was "my" day 16. I've done Ashtanga yoga for 3 years before this, but I can't seem to master the long breaths. I struggle to reach 5 counts, let alone longer than that. In this posture it feels like the space in my upper body for deep breathing is very limited for me. Any advice how to practice longer breaths?

thank you my earth angel, this is what i really need for today, you made my day as usual. miss you as I was sick since 16 Jan. the most I miss is your classes, i was doing your video called "depression"  and really it helps me through my illness, your words make me feel better. hope one day you accept my invitation to Egypt but anyway regardless I can meet you one day or not you will always be my earth angel. thank you

Thank you Adriene. I felt a deeper/more extended meditative stillness than I have ever achieved before using this breathing technique, so thanks for that. I notice that my mid back is not well equiped for sitting up straight like we did for extended periods in this session. I was able to find a few ways to temporarily relieve this pain, but I'm really looking forward to gaining strength in my back so I can sit more comfortably. I have faith that, in time, I will find it.
I don’t know why this exercise triggered my headaches ☹️

how are these yoga practices always so on point? today was not the greatest for me. i had no motivation to practice so it took me some discipline to grab my yoga mat. and i am glad i did, this was such a wonderful experience to stop in the moment and focus on the breath🌼 thank you Adriene for what you do, it means so much for us 💛

This made me so calm. I think because I'm a singer I tend to inhale too quickly, but this was amazing practice for finding some peace in my body. Loved the stretches in between too because my back started to protest a little haha
This girl KNOOOWWWS how to make a playlist! On Spotify she made a playlist love love love ❤️
Love the counting/breathing technique. I get panic attacks, but also general anxiety attacks and I think I'll try to use this to calm myself down. Thank you!

I accidentally did Day 17 yesterday. So I'm doing Day 16, even tho, for me, it's Day 17, haha :) Just a progress report for anyone interested. I was a total beginner. Already wrist pain is minimal. Posture is so much better. I can feel my spine is stronger. I have less aches in my body. I feel stronger & calmer. Thanks Adriene. I can't wait to do a 30 day challenge when it's first live :)

Adriene is human just like you and me. Isn't that why we like her videos, because they are honest and she is being herself? See it as an opportunity to ask yourself why it annoyed you so much and why you were easily distracted in this practise. Finding that out could make future videos more enjoyable for you + you'll learn something new about yourself

Haivng such a health scare atm. Started out crying today but so thankful for the 15 minutes I got where I just focused on my breathing. This is so reasureing. Going to the doctor in two days. Gonna need Adriene before and after for sure.
Yes, a moment of exquisite stillness :)

Hey yogis (and Adriene if she sees this). I have a lot of tics that stop me from sitting still or not "fidgeting." They also affect my neck, so it really hurts to do the neck circles. Does anyone have any advice? I love this channel so much and feel so safe with other subscribers to this channel.

I've had trouble with extended breaths for as long as I can remember. I noticed that I usually breath through only one nostril at a time but doctors told me that's how its supposed to work. But it was weird that i cant do alternate nostril breathing because once i block the nostril which is functioning, i cant force air through the other one. Yoga has drastically improved my breathing and endurance during cardio! I completed this routine with no problems!!
My favorite practice to date on this journey✨ Thank you, Adriene! You have no idea how crucial your videos are for my day to day battle w. depression and trauma. You are a legend and a Saint💛

thank you.

i’ve never felt more at peace than i did just now after the 8in 8 out breath cycle. wow. i almost feel high, i’m so connected to myself.

Thank you Adriene for this lesson! I didn’t expect that we would have a session of mostly breathing but I loved it so much, and I realised how much I needed to slow down my breath. A few times during the session, I was thinking, “shouldn’t I be moving?” I caught myself there, and I realized the discomfort I felt from slowing down and being at ease! So I really loved this timely reminder to take things slowly, one step at a time 🥰 Also I just returned to this 30-day challenge after completing two weeks of it but falling sick for almost a month. I’ve arrived, not early or late, but right where I am 💓.

This day was pretty hard for me! But not because of the breathing. I don't know why, but I could have comfortably breathed in and out for 10 seconds each, if I wanted to (Maybe because I've been swimming for some years back in school, maybe because I am singing a lot and I need to have a sound breath control for this or maybe it has something to do with my naturally low pulse, idk), but sitting in the "easy pose" for such a long time was really difficult for me, even when I sat on two pillows. I guess I need to work more on my (lower) back strength and hip flexibility...

me: :-)

Ok, so listen to this. Next to these 30 days I started working out with a friend and when this title said discipline, I was waiting for a day in which I had energy because I just knew this was going to be all warriors and planks and hard stuff.

Speaking of nerds, if you're like me and like to understand some of the physiology behind all of this, the extension of the exhale longer than the inhale helps to increase heart rate variability and improve vagal tone, which ultimately helps to activate the parasympathetic response, thus signalling your body to relax and regenerate.

First, I wanted to thank you for your practice and your teaching. I noticed you add your own closed captions to your videos which is really helpful for accessibility for many people! It would be great if there were some extra optional directions included. so i just started writing poems this month, and one of them is partially inspired by you, adriene!
i thought maybe y'all would like to read it, so here's the first bit:

the tension melts from my shoulders as
the wind tickling through the long grass
plays with my hair
my eyes close but for a moment

the sky elongates above me
as though i'm in a snowglobe
encased lovingly with silence
and floating sparkling fireflies

gentle brushing blades of grass
bending to touch my ankles
letting go after a quick hello
they return to their places

the only sounds that reach me
my slow breath, the softest song
a personal ocean crashes with grace
and retreats to return

So much growth in this practice!

1) This is the longest I've sat in meditative cross-legged! My mid back really doesn't tend to like that posture; I really appreciate the encouragement to lift hips as needed.

2) Slowly learning how to make the cross-legged pose my own. I can't really tell without a mirror if I'm aligned in head-heart-pelvis, so today I focused on making the posture comfortable. I also permitted myself to pause the video and take some long, luxurious breaths through a repeat of the side twists to soothe my mid-back.

3) Speaking of the twist, "inhale to expand" is finally starting to make more sense! Especially the wide lateral breath...I can feel my spine slowly relax into the twist with each breath!

4) Finally, counted breathing is near and dear to me, as someone with panic disorder who has counted many, many, many a breath. So this practice was comforting. I checked my heart rate on my smart watch during the 8/8 practice...it was at 60 bpm!
Thank you Adriene ❤️

Day 16:

Today was interesting! I was glad for a simple seated practice today (a bit of my spine has been a little twingy after the past couple of days, so it was nice to take it a little easy), but it was interesting to explore something I've suspected, which is that my natural deep breaths are way slower than these practices seem to expect. (I have swollen allergy sinuses eight to ten months out of the year, it's a miracle I can breathe through my nose at ALL). This turned into a great practice in SPEEDING UP my breathing, figuring out how much air I could get in and then back out in only a 3-4 count. How hard and intentional did my breathing have to be to really properly empty it out in only a count of five? It was a good challenge.

And now I and my dizzy lightheadedness are going to sit down for a while.
two days behind schedule but here we go! :)

Found out I hate ratios and breathing out through my nose in general, really hope I'm not alone. It makes me feel so tense and like I'm holding things in. I struggled but I did it to discover new things about myself like you said. I hope it's OK that it didn't sit right with me at this time.

I just finished this practice, 2 days late but at least I did it! After the 6:7 breath ratio I felt really frustrated because I was so clumsy with it and couldn't control it. When she said 'notice how you feel' I suddenly felt a wave of emotion and release and started crying. I didn't end up getting the 8:8 like some others in these comments (well done!) But I just wanted to write this comment to let anyone like me know that it's not necessarily all about DOING IT RIGHT immediately; the breath is our tool that subconsciously knows how we are feeling before we do and it is simply magical that we are able to use it to discover ourselves. If you didnt get it today, or a few days ago whenever you're doing this,just keep going,please 💗 the release will come and it feels so liberating in that moment. Good luck and well done to those of us who are still turning up even if we missed a few days!

Hi! I have struggled with feeling anxious and "bad" when not able to take breaths that fill my lung capacity to 100%. I used to be a smoker and that anxious feeling was a huge turning point for me.

(Below is some advice I found personally useful, but I don't know anything about your anxiety or panic attacks so I also don't want to overstep. You know yourself best!)

However, now I am able to very comfortably take conscious breaths without "bottoming out" or "filling out" so to speak. What helped me personally was acknowledging and recognising that most of the time, I'm never breathing "fully" in a sense of 100% lung capacity to 0%. In fact, trying to force that and sustain it actually makes me feel more ill. The only time I can take a "full" breath is if I concentrate on it and prepare (or yawning also does the trick hahaha). Ocean breath has also occasionally made me feel like I am taking larger and fuller breaths due to me having to put in more conscious effort to fill the same lung capacity I usually do.

Sometimes I have down days and can't take a "proper" breath to save my life. Maybe try ocean breath if you haven't before! Or this just might not be your cup of tea, and that's perfectly fine! 💕💕
@Alicia Albertson Good tip! I felt this way too, so I might try lying down next time.

you showed up! don't feel defeated cause it's not easy!!! I felt that way at first to!! the way to do it is to slooooow down your breath. inhale very little very slowly try doing that ocean breath she taught us awhile back and then exhale as slow as possible. it might take some time to practice strengthening the lungs but it will get easier with time and patience! just like any other yoga poses you may not get right away! don't feel discouraged xx
also i put my hand up to my nose to feel the air come out and it was veryyyy faint. do this right now put your hand up to your nose and exhale fast and hard, now try again but exhale really slowly and the air from your nose isn't as harsh almost like it's not there (idk i cant explain it properly right now but hopefully that makes sense lol) that's basically the secret behind it i hope this helps

For anyone who may have struggled with this today: this type of thing is used by musicians as part of a thing called breathing gym. My college marching band would do breathing gym for 15 minutes every single day to build up breath control so we would be able to play calmly and smoothly while marching. It takes a lot of practice and, yes, discipline to really master. So if this was difficult, remember that this is just like a muscle - it must be built up carefully over time. You are far from alone in your struggles, and your breath control will only go up from here!

This practice reminds me of the exercises we'd have in choir. Some tips that were helpful then and some might keep in mind for this practice: imagine a string coming straight from the top of your head, likes puppet, keeping your head, throat, and torso a nice straight path for the air to flow. Imagine your lungs like balloons, and fill them up starting from the bottom working up to the top. Try and keep the intake and exhale steady, in control, disciplined

2 thoughts: When Bengie kept looking out of the window at a deer, I thought of Blue, our dear departed blue heeler who looked exactly like Bengie. He was a wild spirit and was fascinated by deer all his life. When Blue was not more than about 6 months old and we were walking up a mountainous wooded trail, he ran off and came back with a living fawn in his mouth! "Blue!" I said. I took the unharmed fawn from Blue and we followed him/her back to her mother; then they ran off. It was like a dream.
I'm glad Adrienne left the counting breath practice until now. I think it's more advanced. As I enter our medical center there's a sign with instructions for "mountain breaths", with 5 seconds of inspiration, 7 seconds of exhalation with a 3 seconds of pause in between. These intervals and this counting is too difficult for most people, at least the young patients I teach. I'm glad we had 15 sessions of breath training first.

Of the seven 30-day series since 2015 I am enjoying this one most of all (I love them all, by the way!) because it is quite literally taking most of us relatively amateur yogis into a realm of practice that is not at all about "performance" physically (as most of us in Western society are obsessed with) but is instead guiding us toward an inward journey of integration, letting go, and accepting all that is good, moving us toward healing and wellness.  The breath, the whole body, the sensations, the effort and the mind are all aligning.  Thank you, Adriene!  Please stay profound and quirky!  You are awesome!

Dear Adriene,
I'm so incredibly grateful to you. This is the first time I'm really sticking with your 30 day yoga journey, and at the same time I'm trying to raise a border collie puppy I got on 9 January. I'm learning patience, awareness and acceptance. When I'm trying to get my puppy into a relaxed state of mind, I call it "Benji practice" :) I begin to see very surprising (at least for me) benefits of a daily practice: I am not so afraid to feel emotions (what a strange thing to say), and sometimes I'm paying attention to transitions while trying to find a comfortable position on a couch :) Day by day I'm more stable in high lunge, my toes turn more and more where I want them to in Warrior 1 and 2...I feel confident and proud in Warrior and Mountain pose, humbled and grateful in Childs' pose...I FEEL now, I'm more at ease with myself and - most importantly for me - I'm slowly, veeeery slowly, allowing myself to be proud of how far I've come, to accept and love myself truly. As I grew up in an abusive and dysfunctional family, I'm so happy now to slowly uncover myself thanks to yoga and therapy. I will return to the mat the next 15 days and beyond. Namaste.

Oh, my.  I have been really lucky to have been able to complete every single one of these practices - usually I’m behind by one or two (or more) by the half-way point.  It has been such a sublime pleasure!  Adriene, I have practiced with you for a few years now.  During this morning’s practice, it occurred to me how we have had the pleasure to see you grow and learn - and the good fortune that you have been kind enough to bring us along with you.  Each January brings a new chapter, and so far this is my absolute favorite.  It’s hitting me just at the right time, when I feel the need to practice more wholistically.  And big unexpected bonus- my running is improving by leaps and bounds (pun intended)!  I have found that I hold my torso more vertically when I run, and that makes breathing way more comfortable, which makes running a bit more fun.  I know you have practices for runners (they are in my library) - but I never realized how much cobra and even baby cobra would strengthen my back to hold me in a better running position.  Gifts hidden all around!  Please keep that spark of curiosity for all of us.  Love you! [Apologies for the long message]. : )

Side note, these ratios were super challenging for me, probably for the opposite reason than most. As a classical singer, I’m used to drills breathing in on 1 or 2 and out on 8, 16, even 20. In singing, I’m trained to be able to take in lots of breath very quickly, so inhaling slowly was a good exercise. Even the first 3 was a struggle, and every one after that proved a further challenge, but a good one.

"...a buffet of things you can bring your awareness to..."

This is an excellent metaphor, not just for this practice, but for everyday life. During every moment of our day, we have a 'buffet' of things we can focus on. There are healthy and unhealthy things in this buffet. At times the unhealthy options are the most appealing, but it is the healthy options that give us the greatest rewards.

May your buffets delicous, nutirous, and filling!

Had an unexpected moment of sadness and melancholy at the beginning of today's practice, when I realized we have less than half of this year's journey left. Focusing on my breath throughout the session shifted that emotion into a profound gratitude - for Adriene, this community, and this time. With each breath, a new arrival. Appreciating each moment as it comes, and having the courage to then let it go. It's strange to already feel nostalgic for this series while in the midst of it, but I guess that just signals how important it has become to me. Sending out love and gratitude <3

I love that this practice turned the idea of "discipline" totally on its head - I feel like when a lot of us hear that word, we think of holding planks and warriors and other power poses and pushing ourselves. (I was certainly confused to see "Discipline" along with a be-socked, hair-down Adriene, which usually means a gentler practice.) But of course, the practice that requires the most discipline of mind and body is simply sitting down with your breath. Gentle doesn't mean "not challenging".
Funny. I was postponing to start this video since I was so tired. I was thinking: maybe I should just meditate today. Well.

Today felt like a practice of opposites for me. On one hand, I felt very light and heavy at the same time. And also distracted and very focused at the same time. It was an interesting place to be. I didn’t think I would be able to do the 8:8 ratio of breathing and yet, I did!
Interesting thought: when we exhale, we exhale particles of ourselves into the atmosphere. This means that at some point we have all inhaled each other in at some point. It means that we are truly one with the past, the present and the future. Happy Sunday everyone ❤️

This day was soooo needed. I am extremely tired after a long day out in the snow (far away from people and traffic) and I wasn't sure how to have the energy for this. This was such a treat, to breathe slowly and deeply and to get to a real place of stillness and rest. This practice was amazing and filled me with peace for whole day! That was something special.  Honestly, I wasn't excited about my practice today being about breathing.  But, I'm in this, right?!  So I came to breathe!  And thank goodness I did. My beloved Spanish teacher in high school used to have us meditate and use breath ratios before tests, class presentations, or when she felt as though we needed it. Adriene, you brought me back to that classroom today with this practice, and I felt overwhelming gratitude for you, this community, and that special teacher. I'm going to reach out to her today to see how she is doing. Fostering connections is something you do so well, Adriene. Thank you, thank you, thank you. Xo
Love your videos, we've been following you for years. Question, any chance you can move your mic? We hear your heart beating when you're not talking. Not a big deal.

I had to pause on my daily practice for 3 days, my wrist pain got worse and I knew putting it under any sort of pressure would make it hurt more! Yoga is also listening to your body and knowing when to stop. And this was the perfect practice to come back to. I didn't think I would be able to elongate my inhales past 5, but I surprised myself by getting to 8! Hope you all found this practice as calming and restorative as I did. Namaste <3
I am so grateful for the slower pace today! Grateful from the perspective of how sore I am (particularly my side body) as well as the need to meditate and just BE. Thank you!

Wow, talk about discipline! This ratio breath was really difficult for me. I gave each new ratio a try and did my best and I think that’s what matters. I’ll continue to try to expand my breath techniques as time goes on. This new ratio breath definitely takes some discipline though!
I feel so good right now. Actually using all of my lungs. What a novelty!  But not fair @Adriene to make me LOL at the 8 count with "8 aren't we great! cheerleading routine!"

I guess it’s because I got a habit of breathing deep and on count from yoga and running attempts, but I only felt like having enough space to breath at the 8 ratio. Also, sometimes I like to enjoy a very deep breath, but people around me are always asking why I’m so sad like I’m sighing 😂😂😂
I have the biggest smile on my face after this practice.

I LOVED THIS! I was really craving some movement at the beginning but once I fully committed myself, I found ease. My breath became quieter with each ratio progression until it was barely audible at 8:8. I didn't think I could do it but I really surprised myself. All it took was a different mindset!

I loved this!! It was reminiscent of my years of vocal training. My voice teacher had me slowly empty my lungs as she pressed against my ribcage. I was supposed to keep my ribcage extended as I completely emptied lungs using only my diaphragm. It was intense! This was far more relaxing. I found the slow inhale much more difficult than the exhale. I'm trained to inhale quickly and exhale slowly, with control.
LOVED this one!!  Made my lungs feel all “springy!”  By the way - we can hear your heartbeat ❤️ through your microphone 🤗. Sweet!
Thank you! Loving this!

So much love for this lesson!!! I feel incredibly blessed and relaxed! Thank you so much for this journey!💖💖💖

I feel exquisitely serene after today's practice. I have been really struggling to be mentally present for yoga lately. I've shown up every day for these practices but my mind has been busy and ready to rush on to the next thing. It feels really nice to be fully present in today's practice.

For the first time I could feel what it means to breath and expand the sides! Thank you Adriene! xoxo

Amazing,. I don’t understand it, but I can tell this type of breathing work will help me in so many ways. I’ve already used a bit of the discipline at work and at home - before tough conversations, tough projects, before responding. I’m not sure that’s the purpose of this, but it’s working for me.

breath into all that BLM suffering.

unexpectedly challenging and beneficial! working on our lung capacity is essential in this pandemic!

I started doing yoga ( and yoga with Adriene) last August. Since then I have learned a lot about my own body and my posture and emotional reactions have improved so much. For every moment, for every practice that you share with us. For you been there for me every day. Thank you, Adriene ❤️

today I found it difficult to stay still and focused- this discipline was definitely a challenge for me as i've struggled with really restricted breathing that i've been practicing to deepen. during the ratio counts I found it super hard to slow it down and focus- but when the video ended I tried the 8 count on my own and found it a little easier to slow down. this is def something I wanna work on more!

What a lovely Sunday invitation towards ease.  I use measured breathing to calm myself when I’m highly anxious.  Practicing this in community brought deep peace which is a gift in these times.  Namaste

Normally this much sitting bothers my back. At about the two-thirds point, I noticed my back start to ache. Normally I would start dwelling on that and lose my focus. However, without much effort, today, my train of thought went to, "Wow, how cool is it that my spine is working so hard to support me right now?!"
So what normally would have been a huge distraction, turned into a moment of being grateful. This shift in thinking pattern is a big deal for me.Thank Adriene for being a part of it. <3

Today’s practice was what got me interested in participating in this 30 day journey.  As a flutist, I already practice and teach  ratio breathing as a warm up before I pick up my flute. I still don't want to get off my mat🤣 today I decided to go into the garden and what a fab surprise, a deep breathing discipline. The last 16 days have been a wonderful journey, each day, thank you so much Adriene for your share😍😍🙏😇❤

so today's practice was epic...I finally figured out how to use my yoga blocks to prop up my leg that is in an air cast so I can sit cross-legged!! WOOOOHOOO!  I got SO into the ratio breathing that I forgot I have broken my leg!! I think I won at Yoga today, not that its a competition, just say'in

I'm a Masters competitive swimmer in my 50s. Breathing in swimming is so different from breathing in yoga- we have to snatch a breath quickly at fixed points in the stroke. So Breath is a challenge for me! I had to try hard at the elongated  breathing in but I could 'do' the long breathing out no probs and actually enjoy it !!! Such a joy for me
2nd Half! Sweet Sixteen!! Woo Hoo 💃🏻Thank you, Adriene, for guiding us on this beautiful journey.

Ah, today I noticed how much progress I have made since day one. I haven’t done yoga daily for years and this series was just what I needed to get kickstarted back to it. What a gift. Thank you Adriene ❤️

Does anyone else have the problem of their legs and feet falling asleep/pins and needles when sitting or in forward fold? Happens every time and I'm not sure how to prevent this from happening..

Yep. Especially my left, and especially if I put it in front when my legs are crossed. But it's way better than it used to be after a few years of yoga! I think careful hip work goes a long way. At least for me - my hips are naturally quite uneven so they're often the cause of weirdness. Good luck! I hope it eases up for you!
Wonderful practice today. I will be sharing this day with my voice students on my Voice Studio YouTube Channel. Thank you!!

I thought you might like to hear that two weeks ago my doctor wanted to give me home oxygen. I said let me try to do this month with Adrienne on the breath. He agreed, reminding me to call for the oxygen if needed. So to make a long story short whereas for months my oxygen levels hovered between 88-93, I recently saw it up to 95! First I've had enough hat in many months! Can't prove it of course, but I'm sure your wise guidance and my discipline in returning to the mat every day no matter what is the reason! At 78 I'm thrilled to still be able to find my self fighting for me! not always a pretty sight to be sure but always beautiful in its own way. Thank you Adriene. Namaste!

I'll remember 2020 as the year in which I learned how to breathe. I spent so much time at home and focusing on my breathing (since lack of breath is one of COVID-19 symptoms) that for the first time in my life I became aware of how wonderful it is and how much we can take from it. When Adriene's theme for January came out, I was thrilled and this journey has been even better than I expected. I loooooved today's practice! Not all yoga is about chaturangas, I love this opportunity to look inside and connect with myself. Gracias, Adriene, eres la mejor!
I choose to show up for myself for the next 15 days. Lots of love from a small island in the Indian Ocean <3

Do you mean breathe into your heart? When I began this journey in the era of "I can't breathe," I realized that in so many ways, we can't. We feel restricted, ,limited, hard...

As I sit here, crouched over on the keyboard before I run off into the whirlwind of my day, it hits me, the years of shallow breath, the powering through - and I was a professional poet, yo! I mean, the industry of rhythmic enlightened though subject to the same stress as collectively feel as a society.

I breathed so deeply I felt it in my heart and it opened. How can we all commit to opening our hearts, exposing our soul a little more? How can we expend into our days and breathe deeply as if we are loved. Because we are.
Omg. She saw me. I was fidgeting and she told me not to. THEN.... I had an exquisite moment of stillness and SHE DID TOO. Holy (cat) cow!!!!!!!!! 😍

This was such a wonderful challenge! I found myself really struggling to stay with it, to stay still and focused. When I first started doing your videos I would get so frustrated and upset when I couldn’t “do it right” and would often ditch the practice. Now I’m finding more and more an attitude of “this is the good stuff” where I find challenge. And that translates right off the mat. Truly, daily at home practice has and continues to change my life. Thank you Adriene!

WOW! This practice has sailed straight to the top of my favorites list!!!!! So revealing and super enlightening......I've tried ratio breathing in the past and it always triggered anxiety for me (the opposite of helpful lol), but today I learned something. I realized it's about being graceful with the breath. And in order to fill up, I have to empty. I have to be honest, when I heard inhale for 8 that anxiety tried to invite itself back, but I stayed connected to my breath and I DID IT! Totally jazzed to carry this away with me!

This one was really hard for me and I ended up in tears halfway through and it didn't stop.  Clearly, I get frustrated when I need to really slow down. Sending love to anyone that had a similar experience.

Breathing is so important! If you can't breathe, nothing else matters as the lung association says! Thank you!

I just want to thank you Adriene for all these videos. I've been managing chronic pain for a few years now and have always sporadically chosen certain YWA videos. Last year, like so many others I began a more regular practice and it got me through some of the darker days of lockdown here in the UK. The more I practiced the more I began to connect with and realise how integral breath was. I completed a few of your 30 day challenges last year and this is the first time I've completed it in real time, as it is being released. It's keeping me and my husband grounded through another lockdown here in the UK. I'm noticing my body growing stronger and how yoga poses are beginning to show up in daily tasks, helping me to move safely and minimize my pain. I'm very grateful. Ruth x
Thank you Adriene.

When Adriene gets us to focus on our breath, there are tiny flits of a nothing box for me. Tiny moments where I feel like I'm just released from thinking about things. It's an incredible feeling of just being--just existing.

So, fun testimonial regarding this journey; I had planned to do a 30 day diet and workout from Jan-Feb, adding in some more disciplined time for study and meditation, and cutting out some of my worse habits. Part of that study was working through the book of John in Greek. In chapter 3 of that book Jesus speaks with a man named Nicodemus, and Jesus explains the nature of the spiritual life to him. No surprise here, Pneuma (Greek) and Ruach (Hebrew) can mean either Spirit, Breath, or Wind. After a couple years of practicing Wim Hof I was already pretty keen to the spiritual possibilities of breathing, but I'm very thankful to this practice for helping me to really dig into it right as I'm reading about this super enigmatic relationship between it and our spiritual life!

I used to feel pretty intimidated by the idea of "discipline" because I guess it made me think of failure: being disciplined is something I have struggled with for most of my life (and I still do in some areas!). By far the biggest benefit of daily yoga practice for me has been the realisation that discipline is in fact something that I'm capable of (although it took a fair bit of patience and perserverance - it was seven months before I finally met my goal of establishing that daily practice!). There's a video from one of Adriene's previous series in which she says something about discipline being liberating and I found this confusing at first, but after a year of daily practice, I think I'm starting to understand what she was getting at.

Wow. This was a really special day. As I was doing these breathing drills, I reflected on the types of breaths I see during my shifts as a nurse on a daily basis. I reflected on images of my patients breathing during tonight’s shift. I listen to lungs at the beginning of my shifts, asking my patients to take a deep breath as I listen to the front and the back, each of the lobes. I give them medicines to help make breathing easier, maybe helping to remove fluid from their lungs so they can breathe better. I help them on and off of BiPAP or CPAP to assist them with taking breaths. I pay attention to the muscles they use as they breathe - is there a great work of breathing or is it natural and effortless? When they sleep, I notice the rhythm: is it regular, or are there pauses? And rarely (thankfully), I am at the bedside as I listen to final breaths. During this COVID pandemic my attention to the breath has only become that much more acute. I stood outside my family member’s door while they stayed in my hospital’s Covid unit battling the disease for an entire month, watching the breath, grimacing as I saw how difficult each one was for them. Watching how tired they got day after day just trying to breathe. On my unit, I watched their oxygen saturation while I went about my shifts, pleading with it to stay up high enough. I sighed with relief when they proned and the oxygen saturation improved. While that family member lived, I lost two others to this terrible disease this year. Unrelated to COVID, I watched another family member, at end of life, have their chest rise and fall with the assist of a ventilator. And I watched as the doctor extubated them and they breathed on their own for a time. I remembered how grievous it was to see my loved ones without their chests rising and falling from the breath when their life had gone from them. And as I breathed along with this video, reflecting on the breaths, my chest and belly expanding, my own lungs filling with air, feeling a sense of calm as I slowed my breath, engaging my parasympathetic nervous system, pumping the brakes on the seemingly endless fight or flight mode that is nursing, a sense of complete gratitude washed over me for the gift of breath. Our breath fuels our life. It’s so simple, so astounding, and as we breathe, we are partaking in life. We are blessed with such a gift. And as I finished the 8 second inhale and 8 second exhale, “exquisite stillness” being the how Adriene chose to describe it, i felt something very similar. A moment of complete calm, a respite from the sympathetic nervous system being constantly revved up. That lovely stillness was a gift from the breath. Thank you, Adriene. Thank you so much for helping me find a moment of reflection, gratitude, and peace. My soul was thirsty for that reprieve. ❤️
Thank you for all you have done and all you continue to do. 🙏🏻❤️
Oh my. Thank you so much for this.

This was so good!! I always forget to breathe in daily life, which sounds weird, but I just mean that I have dysregulated breathing patterns sometimes. I hold my breath frequently, particularly when I'm anxious or stressed, which leads me to sigh a lot too. I never used to notice this, it must sound like I am annoyed all the time, but I'm not - I'm nervous! Practising this discipline of breathing really, really helps with that, and really helps to calm me down when I can remind myself to breathe out.
I've also heard that breathing out slowly can convince your nervous system that you are not under attack, and so is very calming.

A tip for you from a fellow anxiety fighter: when you're feeling anxious, slow your breath but make sure you're breathing out MORE than you're breathing in. It's actually over-breathing that makes the anxious feelings happen and snowball. If you don't breathe out fully, the CO2 makes you feel anxious! It's been life-changing for me to learn and I hope it helps you too. Don't be afraid to take in less air when you're feeling like you need to gasp for it. Fight the urge and the anxiety will subside. You're not alone. ❤

Wanted to share a favorite poet of mine today to thank Adriene, see y’all tomorrow!

If you find yourself half naked
and barefoot in the frosty grass, hearing,
again, the earth's great, sonorous moan that says
you are the air of the now and gone, that says
all you love will turn to dust,
and will meet you there, do not
raise your fist. Do not raise
your small voice against it. And do not
take cover. Instead, curl your toes
into the grass, watch the cloud
ascending from your lips. Walk
through the garden's dormant splendor.
Say only, thank you.
Thank you.
-Ross Gay

For the 8:8, I managed to fill until 6, which is a win in my book after thinking I was stuck at 3 earlier. This is definitely a practice I'll keep coming back to, as it's wonderful for the mind and body. See you all tomorrow!

to some (me too) breathing in is harder, breathing out easier - to some it's the other way around. your lung capacity will expand with regular practice, as in actually physically; another thing to do is to try and consciously first breathe into your low belly, then chest, then up. most of us have a habit of just breathing into their chest, so changing "where you breathe to" (your "breath-technique") can already have a huge impact. I hope you'll recover from covid well!! all the best xx

Why are the daily email now coming 6 hours after the video is uploaded? They were very helpful to read before the practice to get in the zone :(

I quite like this lass. However, as I have been practicing hatha yoga since the 1970’s, beginning with “Lilias, Yoga and you”, this is a bit superfluous.
I hope you’re aware that there are hundreds of types of yoga. Hatha yoga is well known in the West. Among other types are Raja yoga, an open eye form of meditation. I studied it in the 1980’s at the Minds Eye Museum on Busch Boulevard in Tampa.
My friend Cowan studied Kundalini yoga. That focuses on opening the chakras, the seven energy centers of the human body.
Then there’s tantra yoga, the sexy one. You can find it for yourself.;)
